title: Effective Altruists: Not As Mentally Ill As You Think
summary:
Key ideas
- The theory that effective altruism selects for people with mental disorders is false
- Effective altruists have about the same levels of anxiety disorders and obsessive-compulsive disorder as non-EA Less Wrongers, but slightly higher levels of depression and more autism
- Autistic people tended to donate a higher percent of their income to charity than neurotypical people or people with other mental illnesses even separated from effective altruist status
- Effective altruists are not unusually self-hating or scrupulous
- Effective altruists are more consequentialist than non-effective-altruist LWers

Key learnings
- Effective altruists don't differ from other rationalists in levels of mental illness
- Both effective altruists and rationalists differ from the general population in all kinds of ways
- Effective altruists are more consequentialist than non-effective-altruist LWers

Key questions
- Why do people giggle when the theory that effective altruism selects for people with mental disorders is brought up?
- What is the connection between autism and consequentialism?
- What is the reason why effective altruists may be a little more autistic?
